title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that there will be a shortage at a wage of $13, does not calculate the shortage as 45 bakers, and/or does not show the work.

Shortage=Quantity Demanded−Quantity Supplied=135−90=45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6643@

The response states that there will be a shortage at a wage of $13, calculates the shortage as 45 bakers, and shows the work.

Shortage=Quantity Demanded−Quantity Supplied=135−90=45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6643@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing number of workers as 90 and/or does not explain that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.
The response identifies the profit-maximizing number of workers as 90 and explains that at that quantity, the marginal revenue product is equal to the marginal factor cost.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the wage the firm will pay as $13 and/or does not explain that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

The response identifies the wage the firm will pay as $13 and explains that this is the wage on the supply curve at the profit-maximizing number of workers (where marginal revenue product is equal to marginal factor cost).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity of output produced will increase and/or does not explain that as each worker’s extra output (marginal product) increases, the firm’s MRP increases, increasing the quantity of labor hired as well as the quantity of output produced by the firm.

The response states that the quantity of output produced will increase and explains that as each worker’s extra output (marginal product) increases, the firm’s MRP increases, increasing the quantity of labor hired as well as the quantity of output produced by the firm.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not state that the firm should rent more capital and/or does not explain that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (2) is less than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (10), or the firm can get more output for their money by renting more capital, or

M P Labor P Labor < M P Capital P Capital MathType@MTEF@5@5@@53F9@

16 8 < 50 5 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C2A@

2<10 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@394A@

The response states that the firm should rent more capital and explains that the ratio of the marginal product of labor to the wage (2) is less than the ratio of the marginal product of capital to the rental price of capital (10), or the firm can get more output for their money by renting more capital, or

M P Labor P Labor < M P Capital P Capital MathType@MTEF@5@5@@53F9@

16 8 < 50 5 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C2A@

2<10 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@394A@
